leanCodeSectionsTree.body:
User notes:
About this chapter: Chapter 8 contains the performance requirements for controlling fire growth and smoke propagation within buildings by restricting interior finish and decorative materials. The provisions of this chapter require materials used as interior finishes and decorations to meet certain flame spread index or flame propagation criteria and smoke development criteria based on the relative fire hazard associated with the occupancy. The performance of the material is evaluated based on test standards.

children.body: The provisions of this chapter shall govern the use of materials used as interior finishes, trim and decorative materials.
The provisions of Section 803 shall limit the allowable fire performance and smoke development of interior wall and ceiling finish materials based on occupancy classification.

diagrams.title: Set-Out Construction
diagrams.descriptionHtml: When finishes are set out beyond certain minimal distances, extra care is needed to prevent fire from being able to spread within the concealed cavity created.

children.body: The provisions of Section 804 shall limit the allowable fire performance of interior floor finish materials based on occupancy classification.
Decorative materials and trim shall be restricted by combustibility, fire performance or flame propagation performance criteria in accordance with Section 806.

For buildings in flood hazard areas as established in Section 1612.3, interior finishes, trim and decorative materials below the elevation required by Section 1612 shall be flood-damage-resistant materials.
Combustible materials shall be permitted to be used as finish for walls, ceilings, floors and other interior surfaces of buildings.
Show windows in the exterior walls of the first story above grade plane shall be permitted to be of wood or of unprotected metal framing.

diagrams.title: Grade Plane
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
The building code defines Grade Plane as a reference plane representing the average of finished ground level adjoining the building at exterior walls. Where the finished ground level slopes away from the exterior walls, the reference plane shall be established by the lowest points within the area between the building and the lot line or, where the lot line is more than 6 feet from the building, between the building and a point 6 feet from the building.

Grade plane is an imaginary horizontal reference plane that vertical measurements for a building are based on. It represents the average of the finished ground level adjoining the building at all exterior walls. On sloping sites, the grade plane will often fall between finish floor levels, and the determination on whether a story is a basement is determined by this. Special attention should be paid to portions of building where the grade slopes away from the building, due to the requirement to use a point 6 feet away from the building (or the lot line, if closer) in those conditions.

children.body: Foam plastics shall not be used as interior finish except as provided in Section 803.4. Foam plastics shall not be used as interior trim except as provided in Section 806.5 or 2604.2. This section shall apply both to exposed foam plastics and to foam plastics used in conjunction with a textile or vinyl facing or cover.

diagrams.title: Open-Grid Ceilings
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Open-grid ceilings installed below sprinklers can obstruct fire sprinkler discharge, reducing fire control effectiveness. An open-grid ceiling that meets 9.3.10 is considered "unobstructed construction" per 3.3.43.2, therefore allowing omission of sprinklers below the suspended ceiling. This section defines the parameters by which sprinklers can be installed only above the open-grid ceiling.

Critical parameters to consider include:
  • Sprinkler design basis (light/ordinary hazard)
  • Style of sprinkler used above the ceiling (spray or old-style)
  • Sprinkler spacing above the ceiling
  • Vertical distance between sprinkler deflector and top plane of the ceiling element

diagrams.title: Combustible Materials in Concealed Spaces in Type I or II Construction
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Noncombustible materials per table 601 are required for Type I and II construction. Combustible materials are allowed to be utilized in concealed spaces per the exceptions provided in section 718.5 as listed below:
  1. Per Section 603 (this section covers insulation, roofing, millwork and many typical finishes)
  2. Materials in plenums per section 602 of the Mechanical Code
  3. Class A finishes per section 803
  4. Piping within partitions or shafts
  5. Piping within ceiling spaces per the Mechanical Code
  6. Pipe insulation and coverings not within a plenum per 720.7

diagrams.title: Walls and Partitions in Bathrooms and Toilet Rooms
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Walls within 2' of toilets, urinals and lavatories are required to be finished in a smooth, hard, nonabsorbent surface to 48" minimum above the finished flooring. Shower enclosure walls and walls above tubs with a shower head are required to have a smooth nonabsorbent finish to a height not less than 72" above the drain inlet.

children.body: Interior wall and ceiling finish materials shall be classified for fire performance and smoke development in accordance with Section 803.1.1 or 803.1.2, except as shown in Sections 803.1.3 through 803.15. Materials tested in accordance with Section 803.1.1 shall not be required to be tested in accordance with Section 803.1.2.

Interior wall and ceiling finish materials shall be classified in accordance with NFPA 286 and comply with Section 803.1.1.1. Materials complying with Section 803.1.1.1 shall be considered to also comply with the requirements of Class A.

diagrams.title: Direct Attachment & Furred Construction
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Spaces behind furred construction can be areas where fire and smoke can propagate. To prevent this, fireblocking or the use of certain kinds of insulation are installed. Alternatively, using non-combustible materials in the concealed spaces can be used, or the finish should be applied directly to the wall surface. When non-combustible construction is chosen, be careful not to allow or specify the use of combustible data cabling or other items to use the open space as a chase. Other materials in this space should meet the Class A ratings of Section 803.

diagrams.title: Set-Out Construction
diagrams.descriptionHtml: When finishes are set out beyond certain minimal distances, extra care is needed to prevent fire from being able to spread within the concealed cavity created.

children.displayTitle: 803.1.1 Interior Wall and Ceiling Finish Materials Tested in Accordance With NFPA 286
children.titleText: Interior Wall and Ceiling Finish Materials Tested in Accordance With NFPA 286

children.body:
The interior finish shall comply with the following:
  1. During the 40 kW exposure, flames shall not spread to the ceiling.
  2. The flame shall not spread to the outer extremity of the sample on any wall or ceiling.
  3. Flashover, as defined in NFPA 286, shall not occur.
  4. The peak heat release rate throughout the test shall not exceed 800 kW.
  5. The total smoke released throughout the test shall not exceed 1,000 m2.

Interior wall and ceiling finish materials shall be classified in accordance with ASTM E84 or UL 723. Such interior finish materials shall be grouped in the following classes in accordance with their flame spread and smoke-developed indices.
Class A = Flame spread index 0—25; smoke-developed index 0—450.
Class B = Flame spread index 26—75; smoke-developed index 0—450.
Class C = Flame spread index 76—200; smoke-developed index 0—450.
Exception: Materials tested in accordance with Section 803.1.1 and as indicated in Sections 803.1.3 through 803.13.

diagrams.title: Direct Attachment & Furred Construction
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Spaces behind furred construction can be areas where fire and smoke can propagate. To prevent this, fireblocking or the use of certain kinds of insulation are installed. Alternatively, using non-combustible materials in the concealed spaces can be used, or the finish should be applied directly to the wall surface. When non-combustible construction is chosen, be careful not to allow or specify the use of combustible data cabling or other items to use the open space as a chase. Other materials in this space should meet the Class A ratings of Section 803.

diagrams.title: Set-Out Construction
diagrams.descriptionHtml: When finishes are set out beyond certain minimal distances, extra care is needed to prevent fire from being able to spread within the concealed cavity created.

children.displayTitle: 803.1.2 Interior Wall and Ceiling Finish Materials Tested in Accordance With ASTM E84 or UL 723
children.titleText: Interior Wall and Ceiling Finish Materials Tested in Accordance With ASTM E84 or UL 723

children.body: The materials indicated in Sections 803.2 through 803.13 shall be tested as indicated in the corresponding sections.
children.displayTitle: 803.1.3 Interior Wall and Ceiling Finish Materials With Different Requirements
children.titleText: Interior Wall and Ceiling Finish Materials With Different Requirements

children.body: Materials having a thickness less than 0.036 inch (0.9 mm) applied directly to the surface of walls or ceilings shall not be required to be tested.

Exposed portions of building elements complying with the requirements for buildings of heavy timber construction in Section 602.4 or Section 2304.11 shall not be subject to interior finish requirements except in interior exit stairways, interior exit ramps, and exit passageways.

Foam plastics shall not be used as interior finish except as provided in Section 2603.9. This section shall apply both to exposed foam plastics and to foam plastics used in conjunction with a textile or vinyl facing or cover.

Where used as interior wall finish materials, textile wall coverings, including materials having woven or nonwoven, napped, tufted, looped or similar surface and carpet and similar textile materials, shall be tested in the manner intended for use, using the product-mounting system, including adhesive, and shall comply with the requirements of one of the following: Section 803.1.1, 803.5.1 or 803.5.2.

Textile wall coverings and expanded vinyl wall coverings shall meet the criteria of Section 803.5.1.1 when tested in the manner intended for use in accordance with the Method B protocol of NFPA 265 using the product-mounting system, including adhesive.
children.displayTitle: 803.5.1 Room Corner Test for Textile Wall Coverings and Expanded Vinyl Wall Coverings
children.titleText: Room Corner Test for Textile Wall Coverings and Expanded Vinyl Wall Coverings

children.body:
The interior finish shall comply with the following:
  1. During the 40 kW exposure, flames shall not spread to the ceiling.
  2. The flame shall not spread to the outer extremities of the samples on the 8-foot by 12-foot (203 by 305 mm) walls.
  3. Flashover, as defined in NFPA 265, shall not occur.
  4. The total smoke release throughout the test shall not exceed 1,000 m2.

Textile wall and ceiling coverings and expanded vinyl wall and ceiling coverings shall have a Class A flame spread index in accordance with ASTM E84 or UL 723 and be protected by an automatic sprinkler system installed in accordance with Section 903.3.1.1 or 903.3.1.2. Test specimen preparation and mounting shall be in accordance with ASTM E2404.
children.displayTitle: 803.5.2 Acceptance Criteria for Textile and Expanded Vinyl Wall or Ceiling Coverings Tested to ASTM E84 or UL 723
children.titleText: Acceptance Criteria for Textile and Expanded Vinyl Wall or Ceiling Coverings Tested to ASTM E84 or UL 723

children.body: Where used as interior ceiling finish materials, textile ceiling coverings, including materials having woven or nonwoven, napped, tufted, looped or similar surface and carpet and similar textile materials, shall be tested in the manner intended for use, using the product-mounting system, including adhesive, and shall comply with the requirements of Section 803.1.1 or 803.5.2.

Where used as interior wall finish materials, expanded vinyl wall coverings shall be tested in the manner intended for use, using the product-mounting system, including adhesive, and shall comply with the requirements of one of the following: Section 803.1.1, 803.5.1 or 803.5.2.

Where used as interior ceiling finish materials, expanded vinyl ceiling coverings shall be tested in the manner intended for use, using the product mounting system, including adhesive, and shall comply with the requirements of Section 803.1.1 or 803.5.2.
Where high-density polyethylene or polypropylene is used as an interior finish, it shall comply with Section 803.1.1.

Where used as interior wall or interior ceiling finish materials, site-fabricated stretch systems containing all three components described in the definition in Chapter 2 shall be tested in the manner intended for use, and shall comply with the requirements of Section 803.1.1 or with the requirements of Class A in accordance with Section 803.1.2. If the materials are tested in accordance with ASTM E84 or UL 723, specimen preparation and mounting shall be in accordance with ASTM E2573.

Laminated products factory produced with a wood substrate shall comply with one of the following:
  1. The laminated product shall meet the criteria of Section 803.1.1.1 when tested in accordance with NFPA 286 using the product-mounting system, including adhesive, as described in Section 5.8 of NFPA 286.
  2. The laminated product shall have a Class A, B, or C flame spread index and smoke-developed index, based on the requirements of Table 803.13, in accordance with ASTM E84 or UL 723. Test specimen preparation and mounting shall be in accordance with ASTM E2579.
children.displayTitle: 803.11 Laminated Products Factory Produced With a Wood Substrate
children.titleText: Laminated Products Factory Produced With a Wood Substrate

children.body:
Facings or veneers intended to be applied on site over a wood substrate shall comply with one of the following:
  1. The facing or veneer shall meet the criteria of Section 803.1.1.1 when tested in accordance with NFPA 286 using the product mounting system, including adhesive, as described in Section 5.9 of NFPA 286.
  2. The facing or veneer shall have a Class A, B or C flame spread index and smoke-developed index, based on the requirements of Table 803.13, in accordance with ASTM E84 or UL 723. Test specimen preparation and mounting shall be in accordance with ASTM E2404.
children.displayTitle: 803.12 Facings or Wood Veneers Intended to Be Applied on Site Over a Wood Substrate
children.titleText: Facings or Wood Veneers Intended to Be Applied on Site Over a Wood Substrate

children.body: Interior wall and ceiling finish shall have a flame spread index not greater than that specified in Table 803.13 for the group and location designated. Interior wall and ceiling finish materials tested in accordance with NFPA 286 and meeting the acceptance criteria of Section 803.1.1.1, shall be permitted to be used where a Class A classification in accordance with ASTM E84 or UL 723 is required.
children.displayTitle: 803.13 Interior Finish Requirements Based on Occupancy
children.titleText: Interior Finish Requirements Based on Occupancy

children.body: Interior finish materials regulated by this chapter shall be applied or otherwise fastened in such a manner that such materials will not readily become detached where subjected to room temperatures of 200°F (93°C) for not less than 30 minutes.

Where interior finish materials are applied on walls, ceilings or structural elements required to have a fire-resistance rating or to be of noncombustible construction, these finish materials shall comply with the provisions of this section.
children.displayTitle: 803.15 Application of Interior Finish Materials to Fire-Resistance-Rated or Noncombustible Building Elements
children.titleText: Application of Interior Finish Materials to Fire-Resistance-Rated or Noncombustible Building Elements

children.body: Where walls, ceilings or structural elements are required by any provision in this code to be of fire-resistance-rated or noncombustible construction, the interior finish material shall be applied directly against such construction or to furring strips not exceeding 13/4 inches (44 mm), applied directly against such surfaces.

diagrams.title: Direct Attachment & Furred Construction
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Spaces behind furred construction can be areas where fire and smoke can propagate. To prevent this, fireblocking or the use of certain kinds of insulation are installed. Alternatively, using non-combustible materials in the concealed spaces can be used, or the finish should be applied directly to the wall surface. When non-combustible construction is chosen, be careful not to allow or specify the use of combustible data cabling or other items to use the open space as a chase. Other materials in this space should meet the Class A ratings of Section 803.

diagrams.title: Set-Out Construction
diagrams.descriptionHtml: When finishes are set out beyond certain minimal distances, extra care is needed to prevent fire from being able to spread within the concealed cavity created.

children.body:
If the interior finish material is applied to furring strips, the intervening spaces between such furring strips shall comply with one of the following:
  1. Be filled with material that is inorganic or noncombustible.
  2. Be filled with material that meets the requirements of a Class A material in accordance with Section 803.1.1 or 803.1.2.
  3. Be fireblocked at not greater than 8 feet (2438 mm) in every direction in accordance with Section 718.
Exception: Compliance with Item 1, 2 or 3 is not required where the materials used to create the concealed space are noncombustible.

diagrams.title: Direct Attachment & Furred Construction
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Spaces behind furred construction can be areas where fire and smoke can propagate. To prevent this, fireblocking or the use of certain kinds of insulation are installed. Alternatively, using non-combustible materials in the concealed spaces can be used, or the finish should be applied directly to the wall surface. When non-combustible construction is chosen, be careful not to allow or specify the use of combustible data cabling or other items to use the open space as a chase. Other materials in this space should meet the Class A ratings of Section 803.

diagrams.title: Fireblocking, Draftstopping and Enclosed Space Concepts
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Fireblocking: Building materials, or materials approved for use as fireblocking, installed to resist the free passage of flame to other areas of the building through concealed spaces.

Draftstop: A material, device or construction installed to restrict the movement of air within open spaces of concealed areas of building components such as crawl spaces, floor/ceiling assemblies, roof/ceiling assemblies and attics.

In the course of construction concealed spaces are created that could facilitate the passage of fire. Section 718 defines where and how the free passage of fire through concealed spaces must be slowed or stopped by the use of fireblocking and draftstops. Where horizontal and vertical concealed spaces meet and in relatively small concealed spaces such as in enclosed wall cavities the code calls for continuous fireblocking at various critical intersections and spacings to slow the spread of fire depending on the concealed space condition. In larger concealed spaces such as attics the code calls for draftstopping at specific intervals or spacing to slow the spread of fire. The materials acceptable for use as fireblocking are defined in Section 718.2.1. The materials acceptable for use as draftstopping are defined in Section 718.3.1.

children.body:
Where walls and ceilings are required to be of fire-resistance-rated or noncombustible construction and walls are set out or ceilings are dropped distances greater than specified in Section 803.15.1, Class A finish materials, in accordance with Section 803.1.1 or 803.1.2, shall be used.
Exceptions:
  1. Where interior finish materials are protected on both sides by an automatic sprinkler system in accordance with Section 903.3.1.1 or 903.3.1.2.
  2. Where interior finish materials are attached to noncombustible backing or furring strips installed as specified in Section 803.15.1.1.
  3. Where the combustible void is filled with a noncombustible material.

diagrams.title: Set-Out Construction
diagrams.descriptionHtml: When finishes are set out beyond certain minimal distances, extra care is needed to prevent fire from being able to spread within the concealed cavity created.

diagrams.title: Steel Framing Drop Ceiling
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Cold formed steel framing at drop ceiling conditions should also include lateral bracing for the tops of the ceiling joists of longer spans. This strengthens the joists and also helps prevent buckling or rotation of the joist. Lateral strap bracing should be anchored to the adjacent stud framing.

children.body:
The hangers and assembly members of such dropped ceilings that are below the horizontal fire-resistance-rated floor or roof assemblies shall be of noncombustible materials. The construction of each set-out wall and horizontal fire-resistance-rated floor or roof assembly shall be of fire-resistance-rated construction as required elsewhere in this code.
Exception: In Types III and V construction, fire-retardant-treated wood shall be permitted for use as hangers and assembly members of dropped ceilings.

diagrams.title: Set-Out Construction
diagrams.descriptionHtml: When finishes are set out beyond certain minimal distances, extra care is needed to prevent fire from being able to spread within the concealed cavity created.

children.body: Wall and ceiling finishes of all classes as permitted in this chapter that are installed directly against the wood decking or planking of heavy timber construction in Section 602.4.4.2 or 2304.11 or to wood furring strips applied directly to the wood decking or planking shall be fireblocked as specified in Section 803.15.1.1.

diagrams.title: Heavy Timber Construction - Member Sizes
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Heavy timber, or Type IV-HT construction, provides fire rated construction by providing a large enough wood member for the charring of the material to insulate the rest of the structural member. In order to be considered heavy timber construction of Type IV-HT, columns, beams, joists and decking must be a minimum depth and thickness. Refer to Table 601 for additional fire rating requirements for heavy timber (Type IV-HT) construction.

diagrams.title: Fireblocking, Draftstopping and Enclosed Space Concepts
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Fireblocking: Building materials, or materials approved for use as fireblocking, installed to resist the free passage of flame to other areas of the building through concealed spaces.

Draftstop: A material, device or construction installed to restrict the movement of air within open spaces of concealed areas of building components such as crawl spaces, floor/ceiling assemblies, roof/ceiling assemblies and attics.

In the course of construction concealed spaces are created that could facilitate the passage of fire. Section 718 defines where and how the free passage of fire through concealed spaces must be slowed or stopped by the use of fireblocking and draftstops. Where horizontal and vertical concealed spaces meet and in relatively small concealed spaces such as in enclosed wall cavities the code calls for continuous fireblocking at various critical intersections and spacings to slow the spread of fire depending on the concealed space condition. In larger concealed spaces such as attics the code calls for draftstopping at specific intervals or spacing to slow the spread of fire. The materials acceptable for use as fireblocking are defined in Section 718.2.1. The materials acceptable for use as draftstopping are defined in Section 718.3.1.

children.body:
An interior wall or ceiling finish material that is not more than 1/4 inch (6.4 mm) thick shall be applied directly onto the wall, ceiling or structural element without the use of furring strips and shall not be suspended away from the building element to which that finish material it is applied.
Exceptions:
  1. Noncombustible interior finish materials.
  2. Materials that meet the requirements of Class A materials in accordance with Section 803.1.1 or 803.1.2 where the qualifying tests were made with the material furred out from the noncombustible backing shall be permitted to be used with furring strips.
  3. Materials that meet the requirements of Class A materials in accordance with Section 803.1.1 or 803.1.2 where the qualifying tests were made with the material suspended away from the noncombustible backing shall be permitted to be used suspended away from the building element.

Interior floor finish and floor covering materials shall comply with Sections 804.2 through 804.4.2.
Exception: Floor finishes and coverings of a traditional type, such as wood, vinyl, linoleum or terrazzo, and resilient floor covering materials that are not composed of fibers.

Interior floor finish and floor covering materials required by Section 804.4.2 to be of Class I or II materials shall be classified in accordance with ASTM E648 or NFPA 253. The classification referred to herein corresponds to the classifications determined by ASTM E648 or NFPA 253 as follows: Class I, 0.45 watts/cm2 or greater; Class II, 0.22 watts/cm2 or greater.

Interior floor finish and floor covering materials shall be tested by an agency in accordance with ASTM E648 or NFPA 253 and identified by a hang tag or other suitable method so as to identify the manufacturer or supplier and style, and shall indicate the interior floor finish or floor covering classification in accordance with Section 804.2. Carpet-type floor coverings shall be tested as proposed for use, including underlayment. Test reports confirming the information provided in the manufacturer's product identification shall be furnished to the building official on request.
Interior floor covering materials shall comply with Sections 804.4.1 and 804.4.2 and interior floor finish materials shall comply with Section 804.4.2.
In all occupancies, interior floor covering materials shall comply with the requirements of the DOC FF-1 "pill test" (CPSC 16 CFR Part 1630) or with ASTM D2859.

In all occupancies, interior floor finish and floor covering materials in enclosures for stairways and ramps, exit passageways, corridors and rooms or spaces not separated from corridors by partitions extending from the floor to the underside of the ceiling shall withstand a minimum critical radiant flux. The minimum critical radiant flux shall be not less than Class I in Groups I-1, I-2 and I-3 and not less than Class II in Groups A, B, E, H, I-4, M, R-1, R-2 and S.
Exception: Where a building is equipped throughout with an automatic sprinkler system in accordance with Section 903.3.1.1 or 903.3.1.2, Class II materials are permitted in any area where Class I materials are required, and materials complying with DOC FF-1 "pill test" (CPSC 16 CFR Part 1630) or with ASTM D2859 are permitted in any area where Class II materials are required.

children.displayTitle: Section 805 Combustible Materials in Types I and II Construction
children.titleText: Combustible Materials in Types I and II Construction

children.body:
Combustible materials installed on or embedded in floors of buildings of Type I or II construction shall comply with Sections 805.1.1 through 805.1.3.
Exception: Stages and platforms constructed in accordance with Sections 410.2 and 410.3, respectively.

Floor sleepers, bucks and nailing blocks shall not be constructed of combustible materials, unless the space between the fire-resistance-rated floor assembly and the flooring is either solidly filled with noncombustible materials or fireblocked in accordance with Section 718, and provided that such open spaces shall not extend under or through permanent partitions or walls.

diagrams.title: Fireblocking, Draftstopping and Enclosed Space Concepts
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Fireblocking: Building materials, or materials approved for use as fireblocking, installed to resist the free passage of flame to other areas of the building through concealed spaces.

Draftstop: A material, device or construction installed to restrict the movement of air within open spaces of concealed areas of building components such as crawl spaces, floor/ceiling assemblies, roof/ceiling assemblies and attics.

In the course of construction concealed spaces are created that could facilitate the passage of fire. Section 718 defines where and how the free passage of fire through concealed spaces must be slowed or stopped by the use of fireblocking and draftstops. Where horizontal and vertical concealed spaces meet and in relatively small concealed spaces such as in enclosed wall cavities the code calls for continuous fireblocking at various critical intersections and spacings to slow the spread of fire depending on the concealed space condition. In larger concealed spaces such as attics the code calls for draftstopping at specific intervals or spacing to slow the spread of fire. The materials acceptable for use as fireblocking are defined in Section 718.2.1. The materials acceptable for use as draftstopping are defined in Section 718.3.1.

children.body: Wood finish flooring is permitted to be attached directly to the embedded or fireblocked wood sleepers and shall be permitted where cemented directly to the top surface of fire-resistance-rated floor assemblies or directly to a wood subfloor attached to sleepers as provided for in Section 805.1.1.

diagrams.title: Fireblocking, Draftstopping and Enclosed Space Concepts
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Fireblocking: Building materials, or materials approved for use as fireblocking, installed to resist the free passage of flame to other areas of the building through concealed spaces.

Draftstop: A material, device or construction installed to restrict the movement of air within open spaces of concealed areas of building components such as crawl spaces, floor/ceiling assemblies, roof/ceiling assemblies and attics.

In the course of construction concealed spaces are created that could facilitate the passage of fire. Section 718 defines where and how the free passage of fire through concealed spaces must be slowed or stopped by the use of fireblocking and draftstops. Where horizontal and vertical concealed spaces meet and in relatively small concealed spaces such as in enclosed wall cavities the code calls for continuous fireblocking at various critical intersections and spacings to slow the spread of fire depending on the concealed space condition. In larger concealed spaces such as attics the code calls for draftstopping at specific intervals or spacing to slow the spread of fire. The materials acceptable for use as fireblocking are defined in Section 718.2.1. The materials acceptable for use as draftstopping are defined in Section 718.3.1.

children.body: Combustible insulating boards not more than 1/2 inch (12.7 mm) thick and covered with finish flooring are permitted where attached directly to a noncombustible floor assembly or to wood subflooring attached to sleepers as provided for in Section 805.1.1.

The following requirements shall apply to all occupancies:
  1. Furnishings or decorative materials of an explosive or highly flammable character shall not be used.
  2. Fire-retardant coatings in existing buildings shall be maintained so as to retain the effectiveness of the treatment under service conditions encountered in actual use.
  3. Furnishings or other objects shall not be placed to obstruct exits, access thereto, egress therefrom or visibility thereof.
  4. The permissible amount of decorative vegetation and noncombustible decorative materials shall not be limited.

diagrams.title: Projections in Nursing Home Corridors
diagrams.descriptionHtml: In Group I-2, Condition 1 occupancies, as long as the corridor width is not less than 96", furniture is allowed to project into the corridor as long as the furniture is attached to the floor or wall, does not reduce the clear width to less than 72", is positioned on only one side of the corridor, does not exceed 50 sq. ft. in area, is separated from other furniture pieces by 10' minimum and it is considered as part of the dire and safety plans in accordance with Section 1002.2.

children.body:
In Groups A, B, E, I, M and R-1 and in dormitories in Group R-2, curtains, draperies, fabric hangings and similar combustible decorative materials suspended from walls or ceilings shall comply with Section 806.4 and shall not exceed 10 percent of the specific wall or ceiling area to which such materials are attached.
Fixed or movable walls and partitions, paneling, wall pads and crash pads applied structurally or for decoration, acoustical correction, surface insulation or other purposes shall be considered to be interior finish, shall comply with Section 803 and shall not be considered to be decorative materials or furnishings.
Exceptions:
  1. In auditoriums in Group A, the permissible amount of curtains, draperies, fabric hangings and similar combustible decorative materials suspended from walls or ceilings shall not exceed 75 percent of the aggregate wall area where the building is equipped throughout with an approved automatic sprinkler system in accordance with Section 903.3.1.1, and where the material is installed in accordance with Section 803.15 of this code.
  2. In Group R-2 dormitories, within sleeping units and dwelling units, the permissible amount of curtains, draperies, fabric hangings and similar decorative materials suspended from walls or ceiling shall not exceed 50 percent of the aggregate wall areas where the building is equipped throughout with an approved automatic sprinkler system installed in accordance with Section 903.3.1.
  3. In Group B and M occupancies, the amount of combustible fabric partitions suspended from the ceiling and not supported by the floor shall comply with Section 806.4 and shall not be limited.
  4. The 10-percent limit shall not apply to curtains, draperies, fabric hangings and similar combustible decorative materials used as window coverings.

Occupancy-based requirements for combustible decorative materials, other than decorative vegetation, not complying with Section 806.4 shall comply with Sections 807.5.1 through 807.5.6 of the International Fire Code.

diagrams.title: Decorative Materials: Group E
diagrams.descriptionHtml: At group E occupancies, storage of clothing and personal items is not allowed in corridors and lobbies. The code makes an exception specific to corridors that are protected by an automatic sprinkler system. The code makes and exception for both corridors and lobbies where metal lockers are utilized for storage provided the minimum required egress width is maintained. Additionally at group E occupancies, artwork and teaching materials on walls shall be limited to 20% or less of the wall area at corridors and 50% or less of the specific wall area at classrooms.

children.body: Where required to exhibit improved fire performance, curtains, draperies, fabric hangings and similar combustible decorative materials suspended from walls or ceilings shall be tested by an approved agency and meet the flame propagation performance criteria of Test 1 or 2, as appropriate, of NFPA 701, or exhibit a maximum heat release rate of 100 kW when tested in accordance with NFPA 289, using the 20 kW ignition source. Reports of test results shall be prepared in accordance with the test method used and furnished to the building official on request.
Foam plastic used as trim in any occupancy shall comply with Section 2604.2.
Imitation leather or other material consisting of or coated with a pyroxylin or similarly hazardous base shall not be used in Group A occupancies.

Material, other than foam plastic used as interior trim, shall have a minimum Class C flame spread and smoke-developed index when tested in accordance with ASTM E84 or UL 723, as described in Section 803.1.2. Combustible trim, excluding handrails and guardrails, shall not exceed 10 percent of the specific wall or ceiling area to which it is attached.

Interior floor-wall base that is 6 inches (152 mm) or less in height shall be tested in accordance with Section 804.2 and shall be not less than Class II. Where a Class I floor finish is required, the floor-wall base shall be Class I.
Exception: Interior trim materials that comply with Section 806.7.

diagrams.title: Bathroom Wall Bases
diagrams.descriptionHtml: A wall base is commonly used in installation of hard surface flooring to cover an expansion gap, cuts when installation of tile or stone has occurred, or in hospitality or commercial settings to provide a sanitary and cleanable edge treatment to prevent damage to the wall.

children.body:
Where lockers constructed of combustible materials are used, the lockers shall be considered to be interior finish and shall comply with Section 803.
Exception: Lockers constructed entirely of wood and noncombustible materials shall be permitted to be used wherever interior finish materials are required to meet a Class C classification in accordance with Section 803.1.2.

diagrams.title: Accessible Locker Shelving
diagrams.descriptionHtml: For locker shelving and storage to be accessible it must be within the reach range as defined in Section 308. In tiered or stacked lockers, the storage in the top locker is usually too high to be within the accessible reach range and the locker is typically not accessible. An additional shelf is typically required to be added at the bottom of the bottom locker that is at least 15" above the finish floor to make it accessible.

children.body: Thermal and acoustical insulation shall comply with Section 720.

diagrams.title: Indoor Dedicated Equipment Space
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Where electrical service equipment, switchboards, switchgear, and panelboards are installed indoors the code requires the volume of space from the floor below to 6' above the equipment or the bottom of the structural ceiling, whichever is lower, to be dedicated to the electrical equipment. Foreign systems, such as the fire sprinkler are allowed above the dedicated space where the electrical equipment below is protected from condensation, leaks, or breaks that may occur within the foreign system. Non-structural ceilings, such as dropped or suspended ceilings, are allowed to encroach into the dedicated electrical space volume above the equipment.

diagrams.title: Open-Grid Ceilings
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Open-grid ceilings installed below sprinklers can obstruct fire sprinkler discharge, reducing fire control effectiveness. An open-grid ceiling that meets 9.3.10 is considered "unobstructed construction" per 3.3.43.2, therefore allowing omission of sprinklers below the suspended ceiling. This section defines the parameters by which sprinklers can be installed only above the open-grid ceiling.

Critical parameters to consider include:
  • Sprinkler design basis (light/ordinary hazard)
  • Style of sprinkler used above the ceiling (spray or old-style)
  • Sprinkler spacing above the ceiling
  • Vertical distance between sprinkler deflector and top plane of the ceiling element

children.body: The quality, design, fabrication and erection of metal suspension systems for acoustical tile and lay-in panel ceilings in buildings or structures shall conform to generally accepted engineering practice, the provisions of this chapter and other applicable requirements of this code.

diagrams.title: Example: Suspended Ceiling Slip Joint Plan: Corridors
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Suspended ceilings should be braced against lateral movement and against vertical movement due to seismic forces to prevent falling and/or buckling. Such a failure not only endangers the occupants from the supported fixtures, but a failed suspended ceiling can also block egress doors. Free joints allow for the movement of ceilings and walls in a way that does not contribute to compression induced buckling of suspended ceiling members.

source: oshpd.ca.gov OPD CL2.30

diagrams.title: Example: Suspended Ceiling Bracing
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Suspended ceilings should be braced against lateral movement and against vertical movement due to seismic forces to prevent falling and/or buckling. Such a failure not only endangers the occupants from the supported fixtures, but a failed suspended ceiling can also block egress doors.

source: hcai.ca.gov OPD CL2.10

diagrams.title: Suspended Ceiling Bracing Wires
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Anchorage of bracing wires may require expansion anchors instead of shot pins in high-seismic areas. The diagram shown is one possible example of suspended ceiling bracing wire anchorage to concrete.

Source: OSHPD OPD No. CL4.10

diagrams.title: Marking of Fire Rated Construction
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
In older buildings, fire-rated walls are harder to spot for an electrician installing boxes or running cables and conduits. Only someone familiar with wall construction and occupancy types will know which walls of an older building are required to be fire-resistance rated. The required markings let those installing future work know that fire-rated penetrations and openings require special consideration so that an unsafe condition is not created by not providing proper fire-rated construction for openings and penetrations.

Verify the exact wording required for your jurisdiction. Note that wording required by the Life Safety Code, if adopted, requires that the type of fire-resistive assembly be identified, whereas the Building Code provides suggested wording. Older versions of the Life Safety Code, such as that required by CMS doesn't appear to have the same requirement.

children.body: Acoustical materials complying with the interior finish requirements of Section 803 shall be installed in accordance with the manufacturer's recommendations and applicable provisions for applying interior finish.
Suspended acoustical ceiling systems shall be installed in accordance with the provisions of ASTM C635 and ASTM C636.

diagrams.title: Insulation at Suspended Ceilings
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Insulation supported by ceilings that have removable tiles does not qualify as part of the thermal envelope's required minimum thermal resistance.

children.body: Acoustical ceiling systems that are part of fire-resistance-rated construction shall be installed in the same manner used in the assembly tested and shall comply with the provisions of Chapter 7.
